byline.contributor: Aaron M. Kessler contributed reporting from Washington, and David Jolly from Paris.

abstract: Volkswagen's admission that 11 million of its diesel cars are equipped with software that could be used to evade emissions standards reveals that problem exists in its core European market; company had previously said problem affected only 500,000 cars, all sold in United States; announces it will set aside about $7.3 billion, equal to six months corporate profit, to cover cost of making cars compliant with pollution standards; scandal has some critics calling for chief executive Martin Winterkorn to step down.
lead_paragraph: The company did not provide information on where the affected cars are, but the overwhelming majority are probably in Europe, where the company dominates the market.

headline.main: Volkswagen Says 11 Million Cars Worldwide Are Affected in Diesel Deception
headline.print_headline: Diesel Scandal at VW Spreads to Core Market

snippet: The company did not provide information on where the affected cars are, but the overwhelming majority are probably in Europe, where the company dominates the market.
